awd_titl_txt: How Social Security Administration Appeals Fare in the Federal Trial Courts
awd_abstract_narration:
With a million case backlog, an average hearing wait time over one year, and nearly 20 million disabled people receiving approximately $200 billion in benefits each year, the Social Security Administration (SSA) disability adjudication process is one of the nation's most prominent policy dilemmas. Despite a standard of judicial review favorable to the agency, as many as 50 percent of the SSA's disability determinations reviewed by the federal district courts are reversed or remanded to the SSA for additional proceedings and, frequently, a disability benefits award.  This project examines why this reversal and remand rate is so high.  

This project will collect, analyze, and make publicly available an original dataset on SSA disability adjudications brought in federal trial courts between 1997 and 2014. The resulting data and qualitative and statistical analyses will focus on the case outcomes in the district courts, the reasons district judges give for their decisions, and the factors that might affect judicial behavior. These factors may include judge characteristics, case and individual claimant specifics, legal precedent, the political and economic environments surrounding a case, SSA efforts to improve adjudication quality, and the judicial hierarchy. The project will provide direct insight into the district court litigation process.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored federal trial court review of denied Social Security Administration (SSA) disability claims. At its outset, the project sought to address what factors drive trial courts to remand high rates of appealed SSA denials of disability benefits. The project also studied how the legal profession has influenced the growth in the number of SSA disability cases and their likelihood of success on appeal in the federal district courts.

The collected data include over 57,000 sampled cases spanning 90 of the 94 federal district courts (excluding are territory district courts) and filed in the federal courts between 1997 and 2014. Within each case, we collected case outcomes, district court, and filing and conclusion dates. We then collected data on a variety of potential explanatory factors, ranging from district judge characteristics, disability claimant characteristics, prior SSA proceedings, legal precedent, and the political and economic environment surrounding a case and the SSA. To examine the legal profession's effects on SSA disability case growth, the project team collected complementary data relating to Social Security disability plaintiff lawyers and law firms and the attorney fees recovered by these lawyers, among other related data.

Regarding the project's intellectual merit, its focus sits at the intersection of multiple disciplines related to law and sciences and science of organizations including law, political science, law and society, sociology, and economics. This project?s database on federal district court cases, parties, and judges promises to provide a new and rich understanding on how federal trial court cases develop and are decided and the role of federal district courts in serving as appellate courts to administrative agency adjudications. While this project?s focus is on Social Security Administration adjudications, many other federal agencies also conduct administrative adjudications that can then be appealed into the federal district or circuit courts, thus making this project's data and findings more broadly generalizable to the study of the American bureaucracy. This project will also inform a rich literature on how lawyers and law firms help shape the legal culture and how the legal culture's characteristics affect the likelihood of individual Social Security Administration disability cases forming.

Regarding its broader impact, this project's data and findings hold potential to affect disabled citizens, bureaucratic policymaking, organizational quality, and judicial review, as well as the federal budget and the future of entitlements. Each year, the federal government pays billions of dollars to millions of disabled people following the SSA disability determination process. However, that process is slow, inefficient, and varied based on an individual disability claimant's location and circumstances, as this project's data confirm. This project's data and findings will help inform discussions on how the SSA can improve its internal adjudication process and how federal district courts can improve their role in reviewing federal agency adjudications. This project also benefitted society through the involvement of dozens of undergraduate and graduate students in the research and data collection, including many women and students of color.
